choices.text: TVS cystic structure; ground glass appearance; bilaterally present
Laparoscopy: brown in color, with tarry thick fluid.
Adhesions to the broad ligament, white colored endometrial implants

questions.text: A 26 year old female patient presents with chronic dyspareunia as well as dysmenorrhea with pain in the right and left iliac regions. She is afebrile without any particular systemic features. Which of the following is an unlikely feature?
questions.solution:
• The presentation here indicates endometriosis in the ovary that is an endometrioma.
  • The chronic bilateral pain in the patient along with dyspareunia without systemic features indicates endometriosis.
  • In such a case cysts have a diameter less than 12 centimeters.
  • However CA 125 is raised.

Incorrect answers: these are true to endometriosis of the ovary

A: transvaginal sonography shows a systemic structure which has ground glass appearance and bilaterally present as indicated by the pain as well as pathology.

  • Ovary is the most common site of endometriosis.
  • Usually involved in up to 30 to 40% of the cases

C: Laparoscopy shows cystic structures which are brown and coloured which have thick tarry/viscous fluid.

  • The brown color is due to collection of hemosiderin pigment
  • Due to their appearance and fluid content they are known as chocolate cysts

D: There are likely adhesions to the broad ligament as well as the lateral adjacent pelvic peritoneum from the endometriosis of the ovary.

  • The peritoneal implants have been classified by the American Society for reproductive medicine into various colors and could be red white or black

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 11, page number: 233-246.

choices.text: The uterus is fixed without adnexal mass.
Tender and soft uterus will be palpable on bimanual examination in post menstrual phase.
Myometrium shows salt and pepper appearance on TVS

questions.text: A 45 year old woman with 3 children comes with complaint of menorrhagia as well as dysmenorrhea. PV shows symmetrical enlargement of the uterus, MRI shows junctional zone of 14 mm. Which of the following is true for the likely condition?
questions.solution:
• The above description coincides with the presentation of adenomyosis
  • This is common in women above 40 who are multiparous
  • The most common complaint is menorrhagia followed by secondary dysmenorrhea.
  • The myometrium of a uterus with adenomyosis will have multiple bright echogenic foci throughout the myometrium - gives a salt and pepper appearance
  • There may also be sub endometrial striations known as Venetian blind appearance these are indicative of the endometrial glands surrounded by the myometrium stroma the glands should be over 2.5 mm deep to the junctional zone.

Incorrect answers:

A: In adenomyosis the try and mobility is not restricted, usually no adnexal mass is felt.

B: Tender and soft tumors will be palpable on bimanual examination; investigation of choice is TVS over TAS as it cannot identify the subtle myometrial changes of the adenomyosis premenstrual phase and not the post menstrual phase.

C: IOC is MRI

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 9, page number: 213 - 215

choices.text: Round cells 6 million/ml; sperm agglutination 12%; living: 52%
Volume 4 ml, pH 7.6, sperm concentration: 45 million/ejaculate
Round cells: 3 million/mL; sperm agglutination 8%; progressive motility 40%

questions.text: Pick the parameter of the semen analysis result which indicates infertility?
questions.solution:
Infertility is seen with the following parameters

  • Here, there is an excess of round cells which normally ought to be < 5 million/mL
  • Sperm agglutination should be < 12 %
  • Living sperms should be over 58%.

Thus this patient will have infertility.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 20, page number: 443-445.

questions.text: Which of the following causes of male infertility will have low LH and low FSH?
questions.solution:
Low LH and FSH are seen in pretesticular causes affecting HP axis or the pulsatile gonadotropin release.

Antihypertensives, including beta blockers, calcium channel blockers and alpha blockers, diuretics, are a known cause of causing pretesticular azoospermia.

Following are the various causes of azoospermia:

Incorrect answers:

B and D: infection with mumps / primary testicular failure

  • These will have gonadal dysfunction - testicular cause.
  • Thus testosterone production is reduced
  • This removes the negative feedback on LH and FSH
  • Thus, they lead to high FSH and LH - not low.

C: Young's syndromes is a post testicular cause and shows normal FSH levels.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 20, page number:442-444.

questions.text: A patient of infertility, with history of PCOS underwent treatment for ovarian function. This was followed by abdominal pain with the sensation pressure. USG shows 8 cm large ovaries. Fluid thrill is present. RR and BP is maintained. Signs of renal hypoperfusion or raised hematocrit not seen. What is the Grade of this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition shown is ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

This occurs when estrogen secreted per follicle is severely increased usually due to exogenous gonadotropin therapy.

Presence of ascites along with increase ovarian size, nausea vomiting and abdominal distension is Grade 3.

Patient to be admitted and correction of hypovolemia to be done immediately.

Following are the gradings of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome:

Reference: William's gynaecology, 4th edition, chapter 20, page number:456-457.

choices.text: Cervical mucus on day 23: lacks ferning pattern
Vaginal cytology on day 19 showing large number of intermediate cells

questions.text: A female is being treated for infertility with Letrozole. Which of the following is not a method to confirm effectiveness?
questions.solution:
• Treatment for infertility with Letrozole is done for induction of ovulation as a drug of choice.
  • Thus, the assessment should be made for positive ovulation.
  • Progesterone measurement on day 14 is inappropriate.
  • Progesterone measurement should be done on D8 and D21.

Incorrect answers:

These tests are appropriate to test for ovulation.

A: Basal body temperature: at the time of ovulation they are raised to 0.5-1 degree Fahrenheit. Which sustains throughout the second half of the cycle and falls 2 days prior to next menstruation. This is absent in an anovulatory cycle.

C: Cervical mucus study: under influence of progesterone after ovulation, the cervical mucus loses the ferning pattern, present due to Oestrogen in first half of cycle. Thus persistence of ferning beyond day 22 indicates anovulation.

D: Vaginal cytology is affected by ovulation. Under the effect of progesterone, the vaginal cells show an increase in the intermediate cells in the second half of the cycle.

Reference: William's gynaecology, 4th edition, chapter 20, page number:433-435.

choices.text: HSG shows proximal block of the fallopian tubes

questions.text: Which of the following is the odd one out?
questions.solution:
A:This is not the gold standard or best confirmatory tests pertinent to the condition. Thus it is the odd one out.

  • Block of fallopian tubes is commonly tested by HSG but it is not a confirmatory or gold standard test. This is because the cornua may undergo spasm in some patients while undergoing HSG, have a cornual spasm, which leads to bilateral cornual block.

Due to this the exterior of the tube will not be visualised indicating pathology where it might not be present.

Options B,C,D are all correct with respect to infertility in females.

Incorrect answers:

All these tests are gold standard or most appropriate tests for the given condition.

B: premature menopause is caused due to reduction in ovarian reserve,

  • Ovarian reserve: shows the number as well as quality of primordial follicles present in a female ovary which reduces with aging and is an indication of menopause
  • It is the second most common ovarian causes of female infertility.
  • It is best measured by AMH levels as it is independent of the pituitary FSH secretion Feedback mechanism. [should be preferred over FSH and estradiol levels]

C: mid segmental block of the fallopian tube is best confirmed by the laparoscopic chromopertubation test.

  • it is the most definitive and gold standard test for tubal patency it assesses both tubal patency as well as the exterior of the tube unlike HSG.
  • Thus it is considered gold standard
  • A dye is instilled through the fallopian tubes and seen through laparoscopy to document the tubal status
  • It also helps diagnose and treat any pathology simultaneously by correction with operative laparoscopy.

D: anti sperm antibodies best test wait mixed agglutination reaction test or sperm agglutination reaction tests which are confirmatory tests to detect the anti sperm antibodies.

  • The post coital test which is the commonest test to check for survival mucus quality is only a screening test for the detection of likely anti sperm antibodies but does not confirm their presence.

Reference: William's gynaecology, 4th edition, chapter 20, page number: 433-435.

choices.text: Histology: atypical simple columnar hyperplasia endometrium cells
Loss of weight and myometrial hyperplasia and hypertrophy.
TVS showing endometrial thickness ≥ 5mm with fluid in uterus.

questions.text: Which of the following features of histology is the result of higher aromatase expression, higher tissue estrogen levels, uncommon in nulliparous women and is a benign finding?
questions.solution:
• The above given description of higher tissue estrogen levels affects several conditions such as
    • endometriosis
    • PCOS
    • feminising tumours of the ovary,
    • endometrial carcinoma
    • adenomyosis.
  • The features except C are all descriptive of varying types of endometrial carcinoma, common in nulliparous women.
  • Adenomyosis is associated with high aromatic expressions and higher tissue estrogen levels however it is uncommon in nulliparous women
  • loss of weight is remarkably not seen in endometrial cancers, unlike most cancer presentations.
  • Myometrial hyperplasia and hypertrophy is characteristic of adenomyosis leading to a diffuse myometrial bulkiness in TVS finding.

Incorrect answers these factors are all applicable to various endometrial tumours.

A: endometrial Histology showing hobnail cells is characteristic of clear cell carcinoma off endometrium it is a very aggressive type of endometrial carcinoma and prognosis poor.

B: Simple columnar endometrial hyperplasia shows around 10% conversion to malignancy when associated with atypia.

D: TVs showing endometrial thickness over 5 mm with fluid in uterus is a characteristic finding of ca endometrium.

Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 9, page number:213-214.

choices.text: Sheehan's syndrome: absent axillary sweating, decreased skin pigmentation, DI, hypothyroidism.
Asherman's syndrome: secondary amenorrhea, caused by aggressive uterine curettage post partum, treatment with both estrogen and progesterone
Sheehan's syndrome: deficiencies of LH, FSH and prolactin more common; gradual appearance if ACTH deficiency seen
Asherman's syndrome: HSG shows honeycomb appearance and must treated with uterine balloon catheter after doing hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

questions.solution:
• Sheehan's syndrome: occurs due to acute ischaemic necrosis of most of the anterior pituitary due to spasm in the arterioles occurring at the time of severe hemorrhage/shock during parturition.
  • Symptoms appear once three quarter of the anterior pituitary is destroyed
  • Clinical features include all given except DI, which is never seen. Thus this option is incorrect.

Incorrect answers:

B & D: Asherman's syndrome occur from damage to the uterus from vigorous curettage, myomectomy, CS, and tubercular endometritis.

Features:

  • Hypomenorrhea
  • Secondary amenorrhea
  • HSG: honeycomb appearance but the investigation of choice is hysteroscopy if possible.
  • Management does include hysteroscopic adhesiolysis followed by intrauterine balloon catheter - prevents synechiae This should be supported by estrogen + progesterone therapy - improves the endometrium.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 17, Page number:374 - 375 [Asherman's syndrome]; Williams gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 17, page number:380-381 [Sheehan's syndrome].

questions.text: A 44 year old female presents with progressive menorrhagia. USG shows a heterogenous, hypoechoic mass against hyperechoic background of myometrium. Which of the following drugs will be given to reduce the size of lesion?
questions.solution:
Leuprolide will cause reduction in size of the fibroid by 40-50%.

Treatment: 3.75 mg monthly dose or 11.25 mg/ 3 monthly dose; IM.

Incorrect answers:

B: progesterone leads to control through amenorrhea but will not decrease size of fibroid.

C: decreases blood loss but not the size of fibroid.

D: OCPs will cause amenorrhea but not control the size of the lesion.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, Chapter 9, page number: 207-209.

choices.text: Multiple small myometrial growths through the uterine wall.
Submucosal lesion due to likely torsion.

questions.text: For a 30 year old nulliparous, married female presenting with menorrhagia and have myometrial growth hampering fertility, with non tender uterine enlargement; which of the following would not be a contraindication for the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The description coincides with that of a fibroid. Considering the age as well as nulliparity of the patient, Laparoscopic myomectomy would be treatment of choice since it would not make the patient incapable of reproduction.

  • The presence of a submucosal fibroid is not a contraindication for laparoscopic myomectomy.
  • It is indicated for type 2 submucosal fibroid as well as subserosal fibroids less than 10 centimetre in size and 4 in number.

Incorrect answers:

Contraindications to myomectomy are

A: Broad ligament fibroids especially when large. - as many several large vessels are present which may lead to uncontrolled bleeding.

B: Multiple smaller fibroid scattered through the uterine wall are another contraindication.

C: An infected fibroid as well as pelvic or endometrial tuberculosis is a contraindication to myomectomy.

Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, Chapter 9, page number:211.

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization: will reduce the size of subserous tumors by 40%.
Uterine artery embolization resolves menorrhagia by 90% but pressure symptoms predominantly persist.
MR-HIFU can be done in myoma of size 8 cm and despite presence of pelvic TB.
MR-HIFU can be done in myoma of 9 cm if uterine size is ~ 20 weeks.

questions.text: Pick the correct option from the following:
questions.solution:
MR-HIFU can done up to the myoma size of 10 cm and uterine size upto 24 weeks.

Incorrect answers:

A: this procedure is not indicated for subserous or SAB mucus tumours as these tumours can infarct or Slough.

B: Uterine artery embolization does resolve menorrhagia by 90%, however it also resolves pressure symptoms in up to 70% of the patients.

C: MR-HIFU can be done in size 8 cm but is exclusively contraindicated in present pelvic infection.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, Chapter 9, page number:210-212.

questions.text: All of the following present with metrorrhagia except:
questions.solution:
PCOS is characterized by oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea due to reduced aromatase activity and ovulatory dysfunction.

Incorrect answers:

All of the following area characterized by metrorrhagia

A: fibroids

B: Ca Endometrium

D: Polyps.

Reference: William's gynecology, 4th edition, chapter 8, page number:180-190.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most commonly associated with Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Here's a concise overview of clinical features associated with different enzyme deficiencies in the steroidogenesis pathway:

Option A: 21-Hydroxylase Deficiency

  • Clinical Features:
    • Adrenal Crisis: Salt-wasting, hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia (Low Aldosterone).
    • Ambiguous Genitalia: In females (virilization), often noted at birth (High testosterone)
    • Early Puberty: In males, Premature adrenarche, accelerated growth, precocious puberty. (High testosterone)
    • Chronic Symptoms: Fatigue, low blood pressure, recurrent infections.

Option B. 11-Hydroxylase Deficiency

  • Clinical Features:
    • Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure due to accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone (Mineralocorticoid like activity)
    • Hypokalemia: Low potassium levels (High 11-deoxycorticosterone)
    • Ambiguous Genitalia: In females, due to androgen excess.
    • Precocious puberty: In males, due to androgen excess.
    • Adrenal Crisis: Similar to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, though less common.

Option C. 3β-Hydroxysteroid Dehydrogenase Deficiency

  • Clinical Features:
    • Ambiguous Genitalia: In females, due to lack of sex steroid production.
    • Adrenal Insufficiency: Symptoms include hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia.
    • Delayed Puberty: In both sexes.
    • Mild hyperandrogenism: in females due to increased DHEA (weak androgen)
    • Under-virilization of males: due to weak androgens.

Option D. 17α-Hydroxylase Deficiency

  • Clinical Features:
    • Sexual Infantilism: Delayed puberty or absence of secondary sexual characteristics in both sexes.
    • Primary Amenorrhea: In females, absence of menstruation, normal genitalia in females.
    • Under virilization of males: Due to decreased testosterone
    • Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure due to accumulation of mineralocorticoids.
    • Hypokalemia: Low potassium levels due to accumulation of mineralocorticoids.

Enzyme deficiencies in CAH

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page number. 118

choices.text: Necrosis due to compromised blood supply

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain and fever. She is diagnosed with red degeneration of a fibroid. What is the most likely pathophysiological process involved?
questions.solution:
Red degeneration is due to necrosis of the fibroid tissue caused by compromised blood supply, leading to hemorrhagic infarction.

OPTION a) Infection of the fibroid: Infection of a fibroid, while it can occur, is not typically associated with red degeneration. Red degeneration is more related to the changes in the fibroid's blood supply rather than an infection.

OPTION b) Necrosis due to compromised blood supply: Red degeneration, also known as caseous degeneration, occurs when a fibroid undergoes necrosis due to reduced or compromised blood supply. During pregnancy, fibroids can grow rapidly and outstrip their blood supply, leading to hemorrhage and necrosis, which results in the characteristic pain and fever. There is leukocytosis and raised ESR. (Differentiated from torsion of fibroid where WBC count and ESR is normal).

OPTION c) Malignant transformation: While fibroids can sometimes undergo malignant transformation, this is rare and not typically associated with red degeneration. Red degeneration is related to changes in blood supply rather than malignancy.

OPTION d) Calcification of the fibroid: Calcification of fibroids usually occurs over a longer period and is not associated with acute symptoms like severe pain and fever. It is a late change rather than an acute one.

Note: The most common degeneration in fibroid is hyaline degeneration whereas the least common is malignancy.

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page number:159
